nodes.text: Applying statistical physics to monetary transactions: conservation of money in agent-to-agent transactions implies statistical equilibrium distributions and explains observed income inequality and monetary phenomena
Money is conserved in bilateral transactions among ordinary agents (local accounting conservation), so money behaves as a conserved quantity in a closed agent ensemble
Boltzmann kinetic equation for pairwise money transfers and its small-transaction limit, the Fokker-Planck equation, are appropriate methods to model time evolution of money distribution P(m,t)

When transaction rules obey microscopic time-reversal symmetry or are additive, the stationary money distribution is exponential P(m) proportional to exp(-m/Tm) with money temperature Tm = average money per agent

If transaction rules are multiplicative or break time-reversal symmetry, stationary distributions deviate from pure exponential (Gamma-like), and multiplicative dynamics can produce power-law tails at high m
Maximum entropy principle explains emergence of exponential distribution as the maximal entropy stationary state under fixed total money constraint; entropy increases monotonically toward this state

Agent-based simulations starting from equal initial money balances and enforcing lower boundary m>0 show evolution to broadening then to stationary exponential P(m), demonstrating instability of equality and the crucial role of boundary conditions

Wealth combines money and priced physical assets but differs conceptually: money is conserved in transactions while wealth changes between transactions via price or quantity changes; therefore kinetic transfer models should refer to money, not wealth

Debt is a promissory obligation distinct from money: borrowing creates paired positive money and negative debt obligations with net zero net worth change; debt is personal, time-stamped, and enforceable, unlike anonymous money

Empirical income data (US Census and IRS) show a two-class structure: majority lower class follows exponential distribution, upper class follows power-law tail; fits support decomposition and theoretical predictions

Boundary conditions (e.g. prohibition of unlimited negative balances) are essential for stationarity; allowing unlimited negative net worth (debt) removes equilibrium and leads to unbounded spread of distribution and entropy

Unconstrained debt growth is statistically irreversible and destabilizing: interest accelerates divergence of positive and negative balances; without restrictions debt will not stabilize and can trigger cascades of default (Minsky moments)

Commercial banks create debt and deposit money-like claims for customers (money multiplier effect), but this process creates liabilities/assets pairs and does not constitute exogenous money creation; reserve rules are a soft constraint and do not absolutely limit debt expansion

When bank-created debt leads to systemic crises, central banks and the state inject exogenous money by monetizing debt (bailouts, quantitative easing), converting endogenous debt into base money and altering distribution of money

Evidence and data linkage: quantitative easing and crisis-era central bank interventions preferentially channel new money into the financial sector, corresponding temporally to increases in the income share and inequality measured by parameters f and G in IRS data

Conclusion: the ultimate monetary source of aggregate capitalist profit and realized interest is exogenously injected state money via the lend-crash-bailout cycle; state money injection therefore contributes to observed increases in inequality
